unnormalised: A property dispute between two brothers, Rakesh and Suresh Kumar, is headed to the Delhi High Court. The case, filed under Civil Law, revolves around ownership of a house at 12, Ansari Road, Daryaganj, Delhi-110002. Apparently, Suresh is claiming sole ownership based on a will he says was made by their father. Rakesh, however, alleges the will is a forgery.
normalised: A property dispute between two brothers, Rakesh and Suresh Kumar, is headed to the Delhi High Court. The case, filed under Civil Law, revolves around ownership of a house at twelve, Ansari Road, Daryaganj, Delhi one hundred and ten thousand and two. Apparently, Suresh is claiming sole ownership based on a will he says was made by their father. Rakesh, however, alleges the will is a forgery.

unnormalised: Adv. Mehra, representing Rakesh, told reporters outside the court that they have strong evidence to challenge the authenticity of the will. The hearing is scheduled for 10/11/2024 at 2:30 PM in Court No. 5. Legal experts say the case could drag on for years, considering the backlog of cases in the Indian judiciary.
normalised: Advocate Mehra, representing Rakesh, told reporters outside the court that they have strong evidence to challenge the authenticity of the will. The hearing is scheduled for tenth November two thousand and twenty four at two thirty P-M in Court Number five. Legal experts say the case could drag on for years, considering the backlog of cases in the Indian judiciary.

unnormalised: If Suresh is found guilty of fraud, he could face serious penalties, including jail time, according to IPC section 420. The outcome of this case could set a precedent for similar property disputes across the country. Stay tuned for updates!
normalised: If Suresh is found guilty of fraud, he could face serious penalties, including jail time, according to I-P-C section four hundred and twenty. The outcome of this case could set a precedent for similar property disputes across the country. Stay tuned for updates!
